title: R41315
content: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) creates new entities, including offices, boards, commissions, and advisory bodies, to implement the legislation. These entities have various administrative, planning, and reporting responsibilities, but their ultimate influence on the legislation's implementation remains uncertain. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) creates new entities, including offices, boards, commissions, and advisory bodies, to implement the legislation. CRS searched the legislation to identify these entities using specific terms. The searches revealed numerous new entities created by PPACA, but it is unclear if all organizations were identified. The Appendix provides a table listing the identified PPACA offices and advisory bodies. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) created various activities and work products, such as demonstration projects, grants, trust funds, programs, systems, guidelines, and protocols. The legislation established governmental units and advisory bodies to implement PPACA, including those required to be established by the President, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, or other organizations. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) created various activities and work products, including governmental units and advisory bodies to implement the legislation. The report lists these entities, their composition, leadership, purpose, and duties. It aims to compare and make general observations about these organizations. The exact number of new organizations and advisory bodies created under PPACA is uncertain. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) created new entities and advisory bodies to implement the legislation. The exact number of organizations that will be established is uncertain, with some sections expected to create multiple entities. For example, Section 10334(b) of PPACA requires six separate agencies within HHS to establish their own offices of minority health. Section 1002 of PPACA establishes an independent office of health insurance consumer assistance, or an ombudsman, that state governments must designate to receive a grant. Section 1323(d) requires state governments to establish or designate state advisory councils, with the number depending on states opting out. Section 5208(b) mandates nurse-managed health clinics to have a community advisory committee. The Patient-Centered Research Institute may appoint expert advisory panels as needed, but the exact number is unclear. The experience of the Administrative Conference of the United States (ACUS) serves as an example, as Congress created ACUS in 1964 but did not provide funding for the agency. Congress created ACUS in 1964 but did not provide funding until 1968. It was eliminated in 1995 but reauthorized in 2008 with appropriations for FY2009-FY2011. However, funding was not provided until March 2009, delaying operations until 2010 when Professor Paul Verkuil was confirmed as chairman. Some provisions in PPACA specify how members and leaders of newly created entities are appointed, such as the Independent Medicare Advisory Board. The President appoints the 15 voting members with Senate consent, serving staggered six-year terms. The chairperson is chosen from the members by the President with Senate consent, and a vice chairperson is elected annually. Members can only be removed by the President for neglect of duty or malfeasance. The Comptroller General appoints the 10 members of another entity. Various general management laws regulate activities of executive branch agencies, such as the Federal Advisory Committee Act and the Paperwork Reduction Act. PPACA specifies whether these laws apply to new entities and advisory bodies. Several advisory bodies created under the PPACA are exempt from certain sections of the Federal Advisory Committee Act (FACA). For example, the board advising the Secretary of HHS on loans and grants under the CO-OP program is exempt from Section 14 of FACA. The National Health Care Workforce Commission is composed without regard to Section 5 of FACA. The CLASS Independence Advisory Council and Preventative Services Task Force are also not subject to FACA. The PPACA exempts certain advisory bodies from the Federal Advisory Committee Act (FACA) and the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA). For example, the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation is exempt from the PRA for testing and evaluating models. Additionally, the Independent Medicare Advisory Board and National Health Care Workforce Commission have exemptions from federal civil service laws for appointing personnel. The National Health Care Workforce Commission can hire an executive director and other personnel without following certain civil service laws. The CLASS Independence Advisory Council members are appointed by the President without regard to civil service laws. The coverage of general management laws for organizations and advisory bodies created by PPACA may vary depending on their location. Entities in the Executive Office of the President are less likely to be covered compared to those in cabinet departments or independent agencies. Legislative branch entities are unlikely to be covered by laws directed at the executive branch. Some organizations created by PPACA have limited lifespans and terminate after fulfilling their missions. For example, the Interagency Access to Health Care in Alaska Task Force assesses healthcare access in Alaska and terminates upon submitting a report. Advisory boards making recommendations under CO-OP also terminate after completing their duties. Some entities created by PPACA have specific termination dates based on completion of their duties or specified deadlines. For instance, the Independent Medicare Advisory Board and consumer advisory council will terminate if a joint resolution is enacted by August 17, 2017. Most organizations created by PPACA have indefinite durations, with detailed provisions on vacancies, member qualifications, compensation, and other administrative aspects. For example, the Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan program advisory board must fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment, while the Independent Medicare Advisory Board requires national experts in health finance and economics. The National Health Care Workforce Commission, Elder Justice Coordinating Council, and Cures Acceleration Network (CAN) Board have specific provisions for member qualifications, compensation, and federal employee details without reimbursement. Members are paid at different daily rates based on their roles. PPACA allows for travel expenses at authorized rates for federal employees serving at the pleasure of the Secretary. The PPACA mandates the Comptroller General to appoint members to various advisory bodies, including a consumer advisory council, the National Health Care Workforce Commission, the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute, and a panel to review demonstration grant applications. PPACA increased the Comptroller General's appointment responsibilities significantly, from 45 positions to at least 128 positions. Some entities, like the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute, are directed to improve evidence on health conditions through research and dissemination of findings. The National Health Care Workforce Commission is directed to coordinate with multiple government departments on related activities. The National Health Care Workforce Commission, established by PPACA, is tasked with evaluating education and training activities to ensure healthcare workforce demands are met, identifying barriers to coordination, and promoting innovations to address population needs and technological advancements. Concerns have been raised about the independence of the Government Accountability Office (GAO) in auditing these entities due to the Comptroller General appointing their members. The PPACA will lead to the creation of numerous governmental organizations and advisory bodies with varying roles in its implementation. Some organizations represent constituencies, gather information, or coordinate agencies, while others have decision-making authority, like the Independent Medicare Advisory Board. Concerns have been raised about the power given to this board in reducing Medicare spending. Some observers have concerns about the power given to the board overseeing the entities established by PPACA. Congressional oversight will vary depending on statutory provisions, focusing on whether requirements are met or if new offices are duplicative and contributing to the legislation's goals. Oversight of the implementation of PPACA can provide Congress with information to decide on future changes to the legislation.
